content: The "Federal Acquisition Reform Act of 1995" is cited as the short title. Section 27 of the Office of Federal Procurement Policy Act is amended to include restrictions on disclosing contractor bid or proposal information. The "Federal Acquisition Reform Act of 1995" prohibits the disclosure of contractor bid or proposal information by certain individuals with access to such information before the award of a Federal agency procurement contract. Additionally, it prohibits individuals from knowingly and willfully obtaining procurement information unless provided by law. Additionally, there are penalties and administrative actions for violating these provisions. The "Federal Acquisition Reform Act of 1995" imposes penalties for engaging in conduct constituting an offense under subsections (a), (b), or (c), including imprisonment for up to one year or fines as provided under title 18, United States Code. The "Federal Acquisition Reform Act of 1995" imposes penalties for engaging in prohibited conduct, including imprisonment for up to five years, fines under title 18, United States Code, or both. The Attorney General can also pursue civil penalties in court, with individuals facing fines of up to $50,000 per violation plus double the compensation received, and organizations facing fines of up to $500,000 per violation. The "Federal Acquisition Reform Act of 1995" imposes penalties for prohibited conduct, including fines of up to $500,000 per violation for organizations. Federal agencies can take administrative actions such as canceling procurement or rescinding contracts for offenders. If a Federal agency rescinds a contract, the United States can recover the amount expended under the contract. Conduct constituting an offense affects the present responsibility of a Government contractor. Definitions include 'contractor bid or proposal information' as information submitted to a Federal agency as part of a bid or proposal. The curr_chunk discusses information that has not been publicly disclosed, including cost or pricing data, indirect costs, direct labor rates, proprietary manufacturing information, and contractor bid or proposal information. The curr_chunk defines 'source selection information' as data used by Federal agencies to evaluate bids or proposals for procurement contracts, including bid prices, proposed costs, source selection plans, technical evaluation plans, and evaluations of proposals. The curr_chunk outlines the various components of 'source selection information' used in evaluating bids for procurement contracts, including technical evaluations, cost assessments, competitive range determinations, rankings, reports from source selection panels, and other sensitive information deemed critical for the procurement process. The curr_chunk defines key terms related to Federal agency procurement, including 'Federal agency,' 'Federal agency procurement,' 'contracting officer,' and 'protest.' The term 'protest' is defined as a written objection by an interested party to the award or proposed award of a Federal agency procurement contract. No person can file a protest against the award alleging an offense unless they reported it to the Federal agency responsible for the procurement within 14 days of discovering the possible offense. The section does not restrict the disclosure of information authorized by agency regulations, contractor bid disclosure, canceled procurement information disclosure, or information withholding from Congress or federal agencies. The Federal Acquisition Regulation revisions must be published in the Federal Register within 60 days of the enactment of the Act, and the proposed regulations will be open for public comment for at least 60 days. Final regulations must be published in the Federal Register within 150 days of the Act's enactment. Certain provisions of law, including sections of title 10 and title 18 of the United States Code, are repealed. Amendments to the table of sections in title 10 and title 18 are also made. Section 32 of the Office of Federal Procurement Policy Act is amended by redesignating subsections. SEC. 3. INTERNATIONAL COMPETITIVENESS. Amends the Arms Export Control Act to repeal provisions related to research, development, and production costs for sales agreements entered into on or after the enactment of this Act.
